node.title: Altering Solution after solving step
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I was wondering if there is a way to alter the nonlinear variable solution after the solving step. I'm doing operator splitting on reaction transport model, I have a kernel for transport part, but the reactions part which solves a simple ODE. So I was wondering if there's a way in MOOSE to alter the solution after the transport problem.
Thanks,
Khaled

Hi Khaled
The canon moose way is to add all kernels and solve the problem without operator splitting.
The transport and the reactions, is this for the same variable / quantity?
If not, then a transient multiapp and transferring the quantities is a proper way to do this.
If they are for the same quantity, then I'd still recommend using a multiapp, but you are going to have to be very careful as to what equation each app is solving and what the final numerical scheme ends up being.
Guillaume

node.title: AuxVariables indexing for nodes
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am trying to solve a variable that is being locally updated on each node where it accumulates over time and used in the main kernel in my application. The updating of the variable is very simple and i am trying to avoid coupling nonlinear variables as the problem is complex as it is. So i think that using an AuxKernel is the way to go.
However, I am not sure how the nodal variables are accessed in AuxKernels, since _u_old is evaluated at _qp, and I am aware also that there is a _nodal flag for AuxKernels but I still do not know how it is indexed for each node and didn't find examples for it. As far as I have seen in the code is that isNodal() function determines whether _qp=0 but it is not clear how to index different nodes. Also, are the initial conditions for AuxVariables are set to zero by default?
This is not a boundary variable, so would you recommend using AuxKernel or Material for this?
Thank you,
Khaled

If your aux variable is nodal type, e.g. LAGRANGE, the Auxkernel will set the value directly for each node. _qp=0 refers to the node. You can use _current_node->id() to give you the node id.
It seems to be correct that IC for aux variables are zero by default.
is _u_old refer to the nodal values or does it always refer to the qp values. Does it get stored at qp or at nodes for the case of nodal auxVariables.

For all AuxKernels and Kernels that access Variables and AuxVariables, the size of _u, _u_old, etc will be set automatically depending on if the kernel is nodal or not. That is, if it is nodal it will have a size of 1 (access nodal value at [0]), and if it is not nodal it will have the size of the number of quadrature points on the current element.

node.title: Stochastic sampling for a function of boundary condition
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE team,
I am trying to use stochastic tool for sampling the boundary condition of my simulations. Instead of sampling a constant value of BC, I am sampling a function parameter "alpha" in function 'bc_func' for my BC. However, when I am trying to transfer the sampled values from a uniform distribution to the function parameter, I get an error saying:
"The desired parameter 'The desired parameter 'Functions/bc_func/vals' was not located for the 'stochastic' object, it either does not exist or has not been declared as controllable."
Could someone please help resolve this issue?
Follows are more details of my input. For the simulation input, I am using the ParsedFunction for the function of boundary condition:
[Functions] [./bc_func] type = ParsedFunction value = sin(alpha*t)+1 vars = 'alpha' vals = 0.05 [../] []
This ParsedFunction is later called in the boundary condition:
[BCs] [top] type = FunctionDirichletBC variable = T boundary = 'top' function = bc_func [] []
The simulation runs fine. The error appears when I try to run with stochastic too. In the master input, I have a transfer block:
[Transfers] [parameters] type = SamplerParameterTransfer multi_app = runner sampler = hypercube parameters = 'Materials/constant/prop_values BCs/bottom/value Functions/bc_func/vals Kernels/source/value' to_control = 'stochastic' [] []

The error message tells that the vals has not been declared as controllable.
You can use MultiAppCommandLineControl  and we discuss that a bit in #18046

Another option would be to make this parameter controllable, but requires a change to MOOSE.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/syntax/Controls/index.html

node.title: PETSc update to 3.15
node.bodyText:
We have a PETSc update via PR #18128
Now we officially support PETSc-3.15 for the MOOSE community. Here is a complete list of PETSc-3.15 changes https://www.mcs.anl.gov/petsc/documentation/changes/315.html
The update is transparent for MOOSE users. The changes should not affect your simulation except that you might see performance gains for large-scale parallel runs. If you run into trouble with the updated PETSc, please let us know.
To access the updated PETSc, conda users could do a conda update ("conda update --all"). For source code users, you could rerun PETSc and libMesh update scripts (./scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh and ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh). Just like any other dependency updates, you might run "make clobberall" to remove old links before you rebuild MOOSE.
If you have any questions, please let us know.
Thanks for your support, as always.
The MOOSE Team

node.title: PorousFlow - Storage units
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE,
I got a simple question. In the GW examples the relation between Specific Storage in Pa^-1 and in m^-1 is simply represented by eq. 11?
Thanks!
Matias
Yes, that is correct.  Remember that, although that equation is written with an equals-sign (=) there are various approximations needed to derive it (hence the preceding "To reasonable accuracy").
Thanks Andy!

node.title: Stochastics - Steady to Transient
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE,
My simulation consists of two scripts. First a script that runs steady state and second a transient state script that uses the output of the steady simulation as ICs. I was wondering of there is a way to run one script after the other one with the stochastic module to perform a sensitivity analysis.
Thanks in advance!
Matias

This should be possible. The main input file will need to use the Transient executioner with two time steps. At the first timestep you will run the steady solves, using a full solve multiapp that runs the input file for the steady. The second step will run a different full solve multiapp that runs the transient input file.
You will need to use the TimePeriod object in the main input to dictate with multiapp will run.
I would start by getting the main input file to run the steady solve, when you get that figured out work on adding the second part.
Thanks @aeslaughter I will let you know how it goes.

node.title: Does MOOSE have 'drainage-only flow' BCs like Abaqus
node.bodyText:
Hi guys,
I'm wondering if MOOSE has 'drainage-only flow BCs similar to Abaqus?
LINK
where we control fluid_vel at the boundary instead of specifying pore pressure at the boundary (Dirichlet BCs)

Kind regards,
Traiwit
Yes, look at https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/boundaries.html and https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/bcs/NeumannBC.html

Awesome @WilkAndy
if I understand correctly, this is what I am looking for, right?
you got it!   You can also utilise use_* things to make the slope of that graph a meaningful number (also documented on that page)
awesome, thank you!

node.title: How to set the non-penetrating wall condition?
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
Can anybody kindly tell me how to set the non-penetrating wall condition in one-dimensional flow?
Just let v=0 at the boundary?
Thank you!
Yuhang

Hi Yuhang
Where is the wall in your 1D system? One of the edges?
Which formulation are you using? Finite element or finite volume? Incompressible or compressible?
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
Thank you for your reply.
The walls are on both edges. The finite element formulation is used in the compressible problem (Sedimentation problem of two-phase fluid).

I think this one
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/bcs/NSImposedVelocityBC.html
is the right one for FE and compressible.
It might depend on your formulation as well. Which variables are you using, conservative or primitive ? (rho, rho u, rho E) or (P, u, T) ?
EDIT: this is for single phase problems btw.
@lindsayad will know better either way
You mentioned sedimentation: does this mean you're using PorousFlow?   Please ignore if this just causes confusion.

The two-fluid two-phase model (six-equation) was built in MOOSE, in which the variables I used are (p, ul, ug,α, Tl, Tg). And I did not use the NS  or PorousFlow module in MOOSE, all the system was developed in my own APP based on MOOSE.

The answer to this depends on a couple things. Are you using finite elements or finite volumes? Are you integrating the continuity equation by parts/are you applying the divergence theorem? If yes, then a natural boundary condition on the mass equation will already have you most of the way there for a non-penetrating condition. If you also want a zero tangential velocity (which it seems like you do) then we'll have to do more than for just a non-penetrating condition.

It's finite element, and it's a 1D system so they're only trying to get 0 normal velocity.
By natural BC do you mean a BC that mimics the action of the kernel? Or a 0-residual BC? I think the latter, just making sure
I should read better
DirichletBCs with value = 0 for the velocities would definitely do the trick.

Or a 0-residual BC?

Yes I was referring to this for natural BC
Thanks for the help. Much appreciated!

node.title: Miniconda download permission denied
node.bodyText:
Hi All,
I am trying to figure out how to install moose on a Windows machine and was able to get everything to work until it says to go to the Conda install. When I try to download miniconda I get the error below:
jbair34@DESKTOP-UHJNGJR:/mnt/c/Windows/system32$ sudo curl -L -O https://repo.anaconda.com/miniconda/Miniconda3-latest-Linux-x86_64.sh
[sudo] password for jbair34:
% Total    % Received % Xferd  Average Speed   Time    Time     Time  Current
Dload  Upload   Total   Spent    Left  Speed
0     0    0     0    0     0      0      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:--     0Warning: Failed to create the file Miniconda3-latest-Linux-x86_64.sh:
Warning: Permission denied
0 89.8M    0   900    0     0   2795      0  9:21:55 --:--:--  9:21:55  2795
curl: (23) Failed writing body (0 != 900)
I tried it without the sudo command as well with the same result. Any idea why it won't download?
Thanks,
Jake

MOOSE is not natively supported on windows right now, you should try using the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL).
See the instructions there
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/windows10.html
Regardless,
I doubt you want to install conda in system32. You can install conda in like programs or your home directory.

Wasn't even paying attention to what folder i was in... That System 32 thing was the issue. Thanks I got it going in WSL.
Jake

node.title: Update MOOSE in HPC
node.bodyText:
I used the previous MOOSE in HPC, so far.
In the HPC, MOOSE was installed as module (e.g. moose/11Oct2019).
Also, moose repository exists in my account (e.g. ~/myaccount/projects/moose).
Recently, I requested to install the latest version of MOOSE and now it was installed (moose/27Jun2021).
I think I need to update the moose repository, too.
But, I didn't update MOOSE and work in HPC so long, I forgot to how to do properly.
I checked the MOOSE website, and I think running the following commands under my account will be needed.
mkdir ~/projects
cd ~/projects
git clone https://github.com/idaholab/moose.git
cd moose
git checkout master
Also, in the website, it told me how to Compile PETSc and Compile libMesh.
I didn't remember I did compile PETSc and libMesh under my account.
I thought cloning MOOSE under my account would be enough.
As far as I know, for using the latest MOOSE, I have to....


load modules (module load gnu/9.3.0 openmpi/4.0.4_gnu9.3 moose/27Jun2021)
-> there is not anaconda/2.7 anymore compared to previous MOOSE.


Update MOOSE repository under my account.
-> use above "git clone" command.


Make application with new MOOSE, again??


I didn't run the commands, yet.
Please tell me what did I miss or what should I do to update properly.
Thanks!

If your HPC people install libmesh and petsc as part of the moose module, it should be ok, and you should be able to skip step 2, unless you need a newer version.
Are $LIBMESH_DIR and $PETSC_DIR set by the moose module?

I don't know if $LIBMESH_DIR and $PETSC_DIR set by the moose module.
Actually, I didn't remember I did run the command related to PETSc and libMesh for previous version.
Does MOOSE module in HPC work as if MOOSE repository?
I mean, under loading MOOSE module, I can recompile an application that I made.
But I don't know if it's because the MOOSE repository itself is in my account, or if it's because I've loaded the MOOSE module.

It depends how the module was created. Is this INL HPC? If so yes.
You can examine environement variables using echo.
So echo $MOOSE_DIR will show you if there s a moose that your application can find to built itself with
Please run this for LIBMESH_DIR and PETSC_DIR so we can see if they need to be installed. I suspect they would be part of the module though

I examine the environment like you told.

Above image is a result after I typed several commands.

The petsc is brought in from the openmpi module.
If there is a different one in the moose module, you will need to export that environment variable.
You need both MOOSE_DIR and LIBMESH_DIR set properly. Please try to locate the corresponding folders in your moose module. If you cant find them, you will need to re-install libmesh and moose yourself.

I can run the MOOSE application with above given environment(old MOOSE), even I cannot locate $MOOSE_DIR or $LIBMESH_DIR.
Is this due to MOOSE repository under my account like below?

I summarized what I will do.
I found a previous discussion that I wrote a while ago (https://groups.google.com/g/moose-users/c/mtbblVWFRqY/m/2DQC89tgBgAJ).
It looks like I tried to compile PETSc and libMesh after cloning MOOSE in HPC, but failed (perhaps.. I didn't load module???)
Just for safety and stability....


(present) ermine and moose folder ->  change name as "ermine_old" and "moose_old"


load modules that I need (module load gnu/9.3.0 openmpi/4.0.4_gnu9.3 moose/27Jun2021)


cloning MOOSE under my account


I think I can skip compiling PETSc because it can be brought from which module I load.


Compile libMesh


Compile and Test MOOSE


What do you think? Will it work properly?

If you are importing a moose module, you should not need to clone. You should have access to a moose somewhere, and can just set MOOSE_DIR.
If you clone, you will have a local version of moose, and do not need a moose module UNLESS the moose module is providing you with PETSC (careful with the openmpi version then!) and libmesh.
If this is still unclear, you should just follow the HPC instructions below and not use the moose/Jun module.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html
